reviews.review: I think, once again, the 'Professional' Critics have no idea the pulse of the people. That was an amazing movie!!!!

Abrams made a film to appease a noisy faction of the fandom. Too much exposition + thin plot + a bunch of spectacle and a whole lot of pew-pew = a hollow film with no soul. I didn't care for it. In short, he bottled it. What a limp and unimaginative way to and a 40+ year old saga I've followed at the cinema the entire way. A massive, empty disappointment.

Complete and utter garbage. Quick cuts and exposition dumps. Characters quickly introduced with no discernible motivations. Nonsense plot with a nonsense villain who has to explain everything he's doing because it wouldn't make sense otherwise. Everything about this was viscerally, offensively bad.
Just a decent entertainment movie, nothing more. For a Star Wars fan it is full of bad plot choices. A bad production that closes the worst SW trilogy.
A very beautiful ending. The few real faults do not change anything.
a dreadful mess. Painful to watch.

The movie had some good moments, but overall just continued with a destruction of the true quality of a good film.  Rey is just a Mary Sue, and it destroys the real story of Skywalker.  The Rotten Tomatoes Audience Score is a farce.

The Rise of Skywalker is neither Epic, nor terrible. It is, however, very interesting...

Never has a chapter of the Saga been so heavily influenced by the previous one, in so many ways, and on so many levels.

It is impossible to correctly speak of, or criticize this film, without talking about the one that it followed. Every aspect of this film, from the pacing & editing, to the script & main plot is a reaction to The Last Jedi, directly or indirectly. 

...and when I say "reaction", I am being subtle. In some places, I would go so far to say that The Rise of Skywalker gives the middle finger to The Last Jedi.

If you are happy to hear that (as admittedly I also would be), don't rejoice just yet. The Rise of Skywalker suffers alot from having to retcon several mistakes, plot holes, and storytelling problems created by the previous movie. 

J.J. Abrams did what he could to right the wrongs of The Last Jedi. And while it is definitely appreciated by some of us, there was insufficient time & space left to unfold the final chapter of the trilogy -let alone the entire saga- properly.

The result is a break-neck pace, crammed full of exposition, action, locations, and emotions, with absolutely no space to breath. Nothing that happens is allowed to settle, rest, or be processed by the characters nor the audience...thus losing much if its impact, gravitas, and ultimately, importance.

Many things in the film are done correctly, such as main character development & chemistry, respect of the StarWars lore & legacy, StarWars locations, language, humor & feel. However most of these things belong in the previous chapter, so as to serve as Set-up for this final chapter. So all these elements, although appreciated, feel severely rushed and crowbarred into this movie. It is strange that this movie isn't at least lengthier, as it could greatly benefit from 30 more minutes of runtime.

The film will certainly be divisive, as it heavily depends on the viewer's point of view (#Obi Wan). Many, who disliked The Last Jedi will approve of what this movie is trying to do, but I think must admit that retconing also creates its own problems. Others who enjoyed The Last Jedi, will almost certainly seriously dislike this movie, although they should admit that J.J. Abrams was painted into a dark corner due to the...lets say "unorthodox" choices made by Rian Johnson in the previous movie.

Should J.J. Abrams have built on and expanded the almost non-StarWars world that Rian Johnson left for him? Could he? Or was he right to backpedal and try to retrofix The Last Jedi's hubris? That's a debate that will probably never end...

What we Can all agree on, hopefully, is that it was a huge mistake by Lucasfilm not to have planned and agreed on a unifying vision for the trilogy beforehand.
mediocre pastiche with an overstuffed, badly paced, rushed plot that still leaves character arcs and plot threads dangling
